items.title: Trump: The decline of the American hegemony
items.author: Sharhan Alhassan
items.description:
The series of events unfolding in the middle east and the rest of the world seem to resemble a typical script of a Brazilian telenovela. Each day passing by with an episode leaving viewers and critics yearning and predicting the next episode. The fold of events occurring on the globe leaves many in suspense as politicians, stock markets, cryptocurrencies, wars, sanctions, and election meddling among others, get to occupy front pages of newspapers and headlines.

Everyday, there is always an episode that political pundits would argue over across media platforms including somethings, families having their own style of newspaper review. The suspense is always high across every episode on global affairs. However, there is one that makes most people uncomfortable because of how zigzagged the storyline is. The storyline is unpredictable such that, one might see a character smiling and assume they are crying. It is nothing than the episode of “ The unpredictable Trump”

Donald J Trump, the 45th President of the United States of America has moved to be the American President, to the middle east President. This spectacle has been in existence for numerous US Presidents for decades. The global hegemony played by the US has made their Presidents technically, the rulers of the world. Clinton, George H.W Bush, George Bush and Obama were all Presidents that enjoyed that unmatched global hegemony. It is rather appalling how unpredictable Donald Trump is with regards to his foreign policy.

Trump has proven in all manners that he can’t be trusted and his unpredictability in his foreign policy is a factor that scares left-wingers. This is evident in his pulling away from the Paris climate agreement, smashing Obama’s legacies (I personally don’t agree with most of Obama’s policies), pulling his country out of UNESCO, numerous changes within his administration, and not certifying Iran’s compliance to the Nuclear deal. The current ‘manufactured crisis’ between the US and North Korea therefore leaves many in fear because, the unpredictable commander in chief of the US armed forces has a close proximity to their Nuclear codes.

This blatant unilateral decisions taken by the Trump administration in the execution of policies that go contrary to international law have rather isolated the US. The US arch-cold war enemy, Russia, has rather utilized this opportune moment to play a leadership role in global affairs with diplomacy. It is therefore not surprising Russia is sanctioned without any substantial reasons under the pretext of election meddling.

USA under the leadership of Donald Trump therefore uses their decade old diplomacy-war-to regain their role in the international stage; spending trillions of dollars on the ‘military industrial complex’. This tool used for uncalled interventions costs dearly the average American tax payer. Many have learned their lessons and would be hesitant endorsing any unilateral invasion or targeting any sovereign country, be it Iran, North Korea, Syria or Venezuela. It is inevitable the US is loosing grip of that power no matter how glued they think they are to it.

items.title: The unending “war on terror”
items.author: Sharhan Alhassan
items.description:
Eliminating Saddam Hussein’s so-called weapons of mass destruction (WMDs), toppling the Taliban-led regime in Afghanistan , saving the Libyan people from “tyrant” Gadhafi, preventing Assad from using chemical weapons on his own people and constant threats and sanctions on the Iranian people.

The above accurately describes the vision that the US/West and some of its allies in the middle east have in a shadow quest to salvage civilians from the threats that ‘intolerant’ regimes in the peninsula pose. The unchanging narrative of ‘war on terror’ cemented during the late 20th century seems to bring more ‘war and terror’ than ever. The Taliban-led government is toppled, Saddam Hussein is dead, ‘tyrant’ Gadhafi is buried, and Bashar Assad is still struggling to control his territories. The US/West and their puppet media designated tyrants are dead now. Then where is the peace?

The time for the world to take one of these choices is getting nearer. We either choose a dictator or total anarchy. The well-hunted dictators in the middle east are killed, and guess what, the killing still goes on and the threat still looms while we still wait to see the rise of the promised democracy. What then is the legacy of ‘war on terror’ and what does it offer the good innocent people of middle east and all around the globe who are under the threats of imperialists, day and night.

The so-called ‘war on terror’ is a clandestine slowly killing waterboarding mechanism used against middle eastern governments that are not marionettes and do not kowtow to the whims and caprices of US and its Western hegemonies. This could be in different forms; not supporting the deadly petro-dollar system, supporting the Palestinian struggle, supporting Pan-Africanism or allying with their enemies.

The sad part of this ‘war on terror’ is that, the ‘terror’ usually move in the direction of the civilians, be it ISIS(Daesh), Al-Qaeda or other groups of proxy psychopaths, and then with the help of their stooges, ‘war’ then descend on them with heavy weaponry. The most pathetic of this spectacle happens when the civilians are made or forced to believe that the regime rather initiates this well-calculated massacre. Sooner or later in the course of the fight, the ‘terror’ gets metamorphosed into ‘moderate rebels’ to fight the regime. When the regime tries to defend itself, then the pro-western media outlets cry out loud: This regime is murdering its people. This is the circle of ‘war on terror’.

It is nauseating the world has not learnt much lesson from the aftermath of Iraq and Libya. Less is done to prevent yet another spectacle of this kind in Syria as warmongers still crave for more bloodshed in the region in the name of democracy and ‘war on terror’.

items.title: What a shame GCC !
items.author: Sharhan Alhassan
items.description:
While some say it is a stab in the back of other GCC members by Qatar, others say it is an act of aggression by the other GCC members to put numerous sanctions on a tiny state with about 2.2 million people. I say, Not at this time. Not at a time where instability is the decorum of the region plagued with a clear power vacuum for varied sponsored psychopaths to feast on the blood of innocent civilians. Why this time ? Why the sudden influx of sanctions to the next door neighbor? Was that a eureka moment to unleash a long hidden agenda?

Whether Qatar supports terrorists or Saudi Arabia supports terrorists or any other GCC member supports terrorists depend on the interest of each country in the war-torn region and how they view it. One would only brand his opponent as a supporter of terrorists provided the US and its western hegemonies endorse them as terrorists. What would you say if a coal pot tells charcoal that it is black. Just like other GCC members, Qatar also has its interest in the region for its stability, but this time around had no rubber stamp from the major power.

The Qatari government is accused of stabbing its brothers in the back by supporting “terrorists” and also deepening its relation with the Gulf’s greatest foe, Iran. I guess if the GCC had rather issued their sanctions to the Iranians, it would have shown how far they are willing to thwart the efforts of their foe. It rather baffles the conscience to punish Qatar with such unprecedented sanctions that their common enemy, Iran, have never even received from the GCC before. Who is then the enemy? Qatar or Iran?

It is no longer surprising that the GCC is now making their enemy more stronger in the region. This now gives Iran more influence to create allies and deepens its relations to establish the principle of “My friend’s enemy is my friend” for Qatar to utilize. This is because, Iran was the first country to openly declare their support to the Qataris and express their complete willingness and readiness to export food products to them should their brothers continue the blockade.

As for peace in the Middle East, it would come to a halt for the Gulf rift to be settled first. This is another interim vacuum for illegal settlements to be established in the west bank, coalition forces could now kill more civilians in Iraq and Syria and blame it on their stooges, ISIS could now re-incubate and launch more assaults. In simple terms, chaos would beget chaos.

Until the GCC come together and stick together against the outside enemy and trouble fomenter, peace would continue to be an illusion.

items.title: IMPORTING PEACE TO THE MIDDLE EAST: TRUMP’S VERSION
items.author: Sharhan Alhassan
items.description:
The long-awaited visit of the US president to the Middle East, mainly Saudi Arabia and Israel, has finally baited political pundits to draw deductions from the visit’s after math. Whilst many are skeptic and doubt the fruits that could be yielded from this historic visit, others still feel the breeze of optimism for Middle East peace; this time around replacing Obama’s version with Trump’s version. As for Trump, he went, he saw, he talked. Could there be any political solution for the instability in the region through this historic visit? Could there be any possibility of importing peace to the Arabian peninsula?

The rate for the now desired “PEACE” in the region seems to be increasing proportionally to the region’s instability. At first, we only needed peace in Iraq after the post invasion. Afghanistan was already in the list of countries that the international community was seeking to see Peace thrive in with Palestine which already made it to the top of the list. Syria and Yemen later occupied a space in the list not long after Libya took a number tag in the list. Whilst Lebanon is making it to the list too, giant strides are made to include Iran. All these countries now need Peace and Stability.

The greatest illusion that Leaders of the Middle East ever have is the long-awaited imported peace that they desire from the US and the West. The belief that western powers would solve their problems and bring peace and stability back to their lands is like entrusting a hungry cat with a fish. There exist almost No western politician that campaigns for power to change the status quo in the Middle East. That is not their priority.

As for the US, I belief they already have a well codified foreign policy that requires every President that occupies the White House to kowtow to and rather openly sing the chorus of Peace for the Middle East. So, in line with that tradition, Donald Trump probably has also sang some chorus from the illusionary Peace after drawing billions of dollars in revenue for the likes of Lockheed Martin.

It should baffle the mind of any rational person to comprehend how Peace could be brought to the Middle east through the toppling of more governments. Yes, more governments. The status quo of Iraq and Libya is enough to teach the entire world that regime change is not the solution for the chaos and instability in the region. It is baffling why some entities, mainly the US and western hegemonies see the only way to Middle East peace is to topple the Syrian and Iranian regimes ( If no regime is to be added for the time being).

Did I hear you say Iran? I know you would be surprise if you are a Muslim because I also used to think that too when people express such views. This is the power of sectarianism that the US and the West exploits from Muslims to continue executing their “Divide and Conquer” policy. It is just like when the word “Terrorism” is mentioned anywhere, what comes to mind? Muslim, right? Same thing when Iran is mentioned, what comes to mind? I am not a Shi’ah? (The writer only expresses his views with no alignment to this sect).

Almost everyone yearns for Peace in the region with diverse approaches. Besides, there are still those who have other opinions either than the Peace that people desire for. War is like a coin with two faces, whilst others abhor it, some make a living out of it. All the same, the majority wish to see Peace and Stability in the region.

items.title: Trump’s ban: Are there traitors in the Middle East?
items.author: Sharhan Alhassan
items.description:
Trump’s ban: Are there traitors in the Middle East?

Some protesters registering their displeasure over the ban
The world has been thrown into a state of confusion over the legitimacy of Trump’s ban on some Muslim dominated countries which include Iran, Iraq, Sudan, Syria, Somalia, Libya, and Yemen. Each of these countries either has a share of about the 57 airstrikes from George Bush or the 563 from the outgone Obama’s administration that got a title ‘collateral damage’ or more deceptively, referred to as ‘war on terror’. Well, the war on terror has brought more war and terror than ever; all this said with less attention accorded to the voluminous economic sanctions and embargos that these countries are also lashed out with for being so call ‘supporters of terrorism’. Just as Bush left the rhetoric in 2001 that any helper of a terrorist is a terrorist, any sympathizer of a terrorist is a terrorist and so on and so forth, that legacy seems to be inherited by successive governments to punish these innocent people and their unborn generations.
When the news of the ban of these countries into the United States broke the headlines, I was waiting for a joint statement from either Organization of Islamic Countries, Arab league, Gulf Cooperation Council or any concerned body in the Middle East. To the best of my ability to be up to date with events of 21st century, I heard none and I read none from any of these bodies yet. A wind of protests rather started to whirl in the west emanating from the United States itself. Other members from the western coccus and diplomatic institutions registered their displeasure to that Executive order signed by the president of the United States, Donald Trump Jr.
My heart bleeds with pain to the kind of consensus Arab leaders have built to the effects of these developments in their doorsteps. The first response I heard came from a member of the Arab leadership from UAE in Gulf saying “ the US has taken a decision that is within the American Sovereign decision” . The likes of Kuwait, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain are still mute on their stands on this important development for the mean time; I guess and hope so. But I guess they were vociferous in pouring their condolences during the Paris and Orlando attacks, weren’t they? Is this hypocrisy? Is this treachery? Is someone being unfair here? Are the British and western counterparts now lawyers and sympathizers of these affected people that are forsaken by their own brethren? No joint condemnation from the Arab League or its leadership? Almost all condemnations are pouring in from the West and not from Middle East, Why? I find it difficult to fathom out what is actually happening. I would ask myself over and over again. This is beyond human imagination.
I would be wasting your precious time to feed you information on all these chaos in the Middle East that drove these people to the shores of US and other countries as refugees due to instability, regime change spectacles and invasions. Well, Iraq and Libya would continue to suck the ink of every generation’s history writers. I wonder the number of airstrikes a country would receive from NATO if it were to militarily interfere in any of its member states, but you could step into Middle East and point a leader and say, “hei man! time is up, pack and leave”. It is ridiculous right? it just happened some few years ago and it is still happening.
Every refugee was once like you, with peace of mind, good education , freedom and happiness. They never thought they would be in their current status quo.
These are some of the touching moments that reignite my belief that, there exists a supreme Being somewhere watching, watching all these chaos and oppressions. There would one day be a way out for the oppressed, rejected and dejected. No one’s blood is sacred over the other, not black over white, Latino over African, or tall over short.
Lets restore the humanity in us.
No #Muslimban

The world has been thrown into a state of confusion over the legitimacy of Trump’s ban on some Muslim dominated countries which include Iran, Iraq, Sudan, Syria, Somalia, Libya, and Yemen. Each of these countries either has a share of about the 57 airstrikes from George Bush or the 563 from the outgone Obama’s administration that got a title ‘collateral damage’ or more deceptively, referred to as ‘war on terror’. Well, the war on terror has brought more war and terror than ever; all this said with less attention accorded to the voluminous economic sanctions and embargos that these countries are also lashed out with for being so call ‘supporters of terrorism’. Just as Bush left the rhetoric in 2001 that any helper of a terrorist is a terrorist, any sympathizer of a terrorist is a terrorist and so on and so forth, that legacy seems to be inherited by successive governments to punish these innocent people and their unborn generations.

When the news of the ban of these countries into the United States broke the headlines, I was waiting for a joint statement from either Organization of Islamic Countries, Arab league, Gulf Cooperation Council or any concerned body in the Middle East. To the best of my ability to be up to date with events of 21st century, I heard none and I read none from any of these bodies yet. A wind of protests rather started to whirl in the west emanating from the United States itself. Other members from the western coccus and diplomatic institutions registered their displeasure to that Executive order signed by the president of the United States, Donald Trump Jr.

My heart bleeds with pain to the kind of consensus Arab leaders have built to the effects of these developments in their doorsteps. The first response I heard came from a member of the Arab leadership from UAE in Gulf saying “ the US has taken a decision that is within the American Sovereign decision” . The likes of Kuwait, Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Bahrain are still mute on their stands on this important development for the mean time; I guess and hope so. But I guess they were vociferous in pouring their condolences during the Paris and Orlando attacks, weren’t they? Is this hypocrisy? Is this treachery? Is someone being unfair here? Are the British and western counterparts now lawyers and sympathizers of these affected people that are forsaken by their own brethren? No joint condemnation from the Arab League or its leadership? Almost all condemnations are pouring in from the West and not from Middle East, Why? I find it difficult to fathom out what is actually happening. I would ask myself over and over again. This is beyond human imagination.

I would be wasting your precious time to feed you information on all these chaos in the Middle East that drove these people to the shores of US and other countries as refugees due to instability, regime change spectacles and invasions. Well, Iraq and Libya would continue to suck the ink of every generation’s history writers. I wonder the number of airstrikes a country would receive from NATO if it were to militarily interfere in any of its member states, but you could step into Middle East and point a leader and say, “hei man! time is up, pack and leave”. It is ridiculous right? it just happened some few years ago and it is still happening.

Every refugee was once like you, with peace of mind, good education , freedom and happiness. They never thought they would be in their current status quo.

These are some of the touching moments that reignite my belief that, there exists a supreme Being somewhere watching, watching all these chaos and oppressions. There would one day be a way out for the oppressed, rejected and dejected. No one’s blood is sacred over the other, not black over white, Latino over African, or tall over short.

Lets restore the humanity in us.

No #Muslimban
